fields.name: Time signature
fields.description:
A time signature in MNX is defined as a sum of ordered, undotted note value quantities that define the meter of a measure. Some examples:

Time signatureEncoding
Four-four time4/4
Three quarters time3/4
A compound time signature of 2/8, 3/8 and 2/8, with 2+3+2 over the shared denominator 8.2+3+2/8
A compound time signature of 2/8, 3/4 and 2/8 as separate fractions (note that the spaces are ignored).2/8 + 3/4 + 2/8

Algorithm for parsing

To parse a time signature, use the following procedure:

  1. Let input be the string being parsed.
  2. Let tokens be the result of strictly splitting the string input using U+002B PLUS as a delimiter.
  3. If tokens is empty, return an error.
  4. Let shared denominator be true.
  5. Let fractions be an empty list.
  6. While tokens is not empty,
    1. Remove the first element of tokens and assign it to t after stripping leading and trailing whitespace.
    2. If t contains the characters U+002F SLASH or U+002A ASTERISK,<
      1. Let nv be the result of parsing t as a note value quantity.
      2. If nv has a number of dots greater than zero, return an error.
      3. If shared denominator is true,
        1. Replace the denominator in each element of fractions with the denominator of nv.
        2. If more elements remain in tokens, set shared denominator to false.
        3. Append nv to fractions.
      4. Else,
        1. If tokens is empty, return an error.
        2. If shared denominator is false, return an error.
        3. Let numerator be the result of parsing t as a valid integer.
        4. Append the fraction composed of numerator and the denominator 1 to fractions.
  7. Return fractions and shared denominator as the result.

fields.name: Staff line
fields.description: A specific line of the staff, as represented by a number. The bottom line on the staff is 1, and higher staff lines increase upward in value.

fields.name: Note value
fields.description:
MNX encodes note values in a microsyntax. Some examples:

Note valueEncoding
A whole note/1
A half note/2
A quarter note/4
An eighth note/8
A dotted eighth note/8d
A double-dotted eighth note/8dd
A breve (double whole note)*2
A dotted breve*2d

Syntax definition

Note values less than or equal to a whole note consist of the following, in order:

  1. The character U+002F SLASH.
  2. One or more ASCII digits encoding the rhythmic duration as a power-of-two fractional denominator.
  3. Zero or more occurrences of U+0064 LOWERCASE D characters — one for each augmentation dot.

Note values greater than a whole note consist of the following, in order:

  1. The character U+002A ASTERISK.
  2. One or more ASCII digits encoding the base note value as a power-of-two multiplying factor.
  3. Zero or more occurrences of U+0064 LOWERCASE D characters — one for each augmentation dot.

Algorithm for parsing

To parse a note value, use the following procedure:

  1. Let input be the string being parsed.
  2. Let position be a pointer into input, initially pointing at the start of the string.
  3. Let number of dots be 0.
  4. If the character indicated by position is a U+002A ASTERISK character (*), let fractional be false and advance position by 1.
  5. Else, if the character indicated by position is a U+002E SLASH character (/), let fractional be true and advance position by 1.
  6. Else, return an error.
  7. Collect a sequence of characters that are ASCII digits only and let unparsed number be the result.
  8. Let base value be the result of parsing unparsed number using the rules for parsing integers.
  9. Collect a sequence of characters that are U+0064 LOWERCASE D characters. Set number of dots to the length of this sequence.
  10. If position is not at the end of the string, return an error.
  11. If base value is not equal to a power of 2, return an error.
  12. If base value is equal to 1 and fractional is false, return an error.
  13. If fractional is true, set base value to (1 / base value).
  14. Return base value and number of dots.

fields.name: Chromatic pitch
fields.description:
MNX encodes chromatic pitches in a microsyntax. Some examples:

Chromatic pitchEncoding
Middle CC4
The C-sharp above middle CC#4
The D-flat above middle CDb4
The D-double-flat very near middle CDbb4
The pitch one quarter-tone above middle CC4+0.5
The pitch one quarter-tone above middle C (identical to the above, but expressed in whole tone units)C4+0.25w
The pitch one quarter-tone above middle C (identical to the above, but expressed as whole tone fraction)C4+1/4w
The pitch one quarter-tone above middle C (identical to the above, but expressed as octave fraction)C4+1/24o

Algorithm for parsing

To parse a chromatic pitch, use the following procedure:

  1. Let input be the string being parsed.
  2. Let position be a pointer into input, initially pointing at the start of the string.
  3. Let alteration be 0.
  4. If the character at position is not an uppercase ASCII letter in the range from U+0041 UPPERCASE A - U+0047 UPPERCASE G, return an error.
  5. Let step be the character at position, and advance position by 1.
  6. If the character at position is U+0023 HASH,
    1. While the character at position is U+0023 HASH,
      1. Increase alteration by 1.
      2. Advance position by 1.
  7. Else, if the character at position is U+0062 b,
    1. While the character at position is U+0062 b,
      1. Decrease alteration by 1.
      2. Advance position by 1.
  8. Collect a sequence of characters that are ASCII digits only and let unparsed number be the result.
  9. Let octave be the result of parsing unparsed number using the rules for parsing integers.
  10. Let alteration factor be 0.
  11. If the character at position is U+002B PLUS,
    1. Set alteration factor to 1.
    2. Advance position by 1.
  12. If the character at position is U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS,
    1. Set alteration factor to -1.
    2. Advance position by 1.
  13. If alteration factor is not equal to zero,
    1. Collect a sequence of characters that are ASCII digits, U+002E FULL STOP, or U+002F SLASH and place the result in unparsed number.
    2. If the character at position is U+006F LOWERCASE o,
      1. Multiply alteration factor by 12.
      2. Advance position by 1.
    3. Else, if the character at position is U+0077 LOWERCASE w,
      1. Multiply alteration factor by 2.
      2. Advance position by 1.
    4. If unparsed number contains U+002F SLASH, parse it as a rational number. Otherwise parse it as a valid floating-point number. Multiply the result by alteration factor and add this to alteration.
  14. If position is not at the end of the string, return an error.
  15. Return step, octave and alteration.

fields.name: Note value quantity
fields.description:
A note value quantity is an integer multiple of a note value. Some examples:

Note value quantityEncoding
A single eighth note/8
Six eighth notes6/8
Six dotted eighth notes6/8d
Five whole notes5/1

Syntax definition

A note value quantity consists of the following, in order:

  1. Zero or more ASCII digits encoding the multiplier.
  2. A note value.

Algorithm for parsing

To parse a note value quantity, use the following procedure:

  1. Let input be the string being parsed.
  2. Let position be a pointer into input, initially pointing at the start of the string.
  3. Let multiplier be 1.
  4. Collect a sequence of characters that are ASCII digits only, and let unparsed number be the result.
  5. If unparsed number is not empty, assign unparsed number to multiplier using the rules for parsing integers.
  6. Let note value be the result of parsing the remainder of the string beginning at position according to the algorithm for parsing a note value.
  7. Return multiplier and note value.

fields.name: Measure location
fields.description:
An MNX measure location describes a specific location of a musical event in terms of a measure's content. Some examples:

Measure locationEncoding
One quarter note after the start of the containing measure0.25
Three eighth notes after the start of the containing measure3/8
One quarter note after the start of the measure with index 44:0.25
The same as the preceding example4:1/4
The same metrical position as the event whose ID is event235#event235

Syntax definition

There are three possible syntaxes for measure locations:

  1. If the measure location is a metrical position in the context of the containing measure, then it is specified as a valid floating-point number or note value quantity that gives the number of whole notes from the start of the measure.
  2. If the measure location is a metrical position in the context of an arbitrary <measure> in the document, then it is specified as a pair of tokens separated by U+003A COLON. The first token is a measure number identifying the measure, and the second token is a valid floating-point number or note value quantity that gives the number of whole notes from the start of the identified measure. The identified measure must belong to the same measure content as the element in which the measure location is given. This requirement has the effect of ensuring that the measure index is unique, since measure locations cannot reference measures in other systems with different barring.
  3. If the measure location is identical to the metrical position of some known <event> in the score, then it can be specified as a element location identifying the event. The identified event must belong to the same measure content as the element in which the measure location is given.

fields.name: Slur/tie end location
fields.description: This is a measure location representing the "other" end of a slur or tie, with two special values "incoming" or "outgoing".

fields.name: Orientation
fields.description: This specifies the placement and rendering of content.

fields.name: Staff index
fields.description:
The one-based numeric index of a staff within a part. In a single-staff part, this will be "1". In a grand staff part (which has two staves), the top staff has staff index "1" and the bottom staff has staff index "2".

Within a part, staff indexes should always increment by 1. For example, it's an error for a two-staff part to use staff indexes "1" and "3".

fields.name: Integer (signed)
fields.description: As defined at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#signed-integers

fields.name: Simple color
fields.description: A simple color is a seven-character string representing the red, green and blue components of a color, as defined in the HTML standard. This is commonly known as a hexcode or hex value. Examples: #000000 (black), #ff0000 (red).

fields.name: SMuFL glyph name
fields.description: A string representing a glyph name in the SMuFL music-font-encoding specification. In MNX, this is generally used to override default engraving behavior. Example SMuFL glyph name: noteheadXOrnateEllipse

fields.name: Stem direction
fields.description: Describes whether the stem is pointed up or down.

fields.name: Measure number
fields.description: An integer representing a measure number, where the first measure in a score is generally 1.

fields.name: Voice ID
fields.description:
A string used to identify a voice within an MNX document.

This is an opaque identifier that does not supply information from producers to consumers.

fields.name: Tuplet display setting
fields.description: Controls the display of a tuplet's note value units.

fields.name: SMuFL font name
fields.description: The name of a SMuFL-compliant font.

fields.name: Visibility option
fields.description:
This controls whether an element's contents (including all of its descendents) are displayed by a consumer.

In contrast to "display: none", "visibility: hidden" does not affect the layout of any other elements in the document. For example, the contents of a hidden <event> will not be shown, but the place where the event would have appeared will still occupy space in the containing measure.

fields.name: Perform option
fields.description:
This specifies whether an element is performed by consuming software.

For example, if consuming software offers synthetic playback, specifying perform="none" for a <note> element means the note will be excluded from playback (but still visually rendered).

fields.name: Stave count
fields.description: The number of staves used in a given part. This must be an integer greater than or equal to 1.

fields.name: System layout ID
fields.description:
A string used to identify a system layout in the MNX document. This must contain no spaces, and it is case-sensitive.

Examples: "fullscorelayout", "flutepartlayout".

fields.name: Element location
fields.description: An element location constitutes a reference to a specific element in the current document. It consists of the character #, immediately followed by the XML ID of the referenced element.

fields.name: Floating point number
fields.description: A valid floating point number, as described here.

fields.name: Style class
fields.description: A style class is a string, defined by a <style>, that styleable MNX elements can use to declare they should be styled.

fields.name: CSS selector
fields.description:
A CSS-style selector that is used by the <style> element to define which element(s) are targeted.

MNX does not support the full complexity of CSS. For now, only two types of selectors are supported:

  • Element selectors allow selecting any MNX element of the given name.
  • Class selectors allow selecting any MNX element that contains the given class.

An element selector is simply the element name without any additional syntax:

<style selector="note" ...>

A class selector is the class name with a dot in front of it:

<style selector=".bolded" ...>
The run of grace notes occupies a time interval that ends before the expected onset of the next non-grace event, shortening the duration of the preceding non-grace event.
The run of grace notes occupies a time interval starting at the expected onset of the next non-grace event, both delaying its onset and shortening its duration.
The run of grace notes delays the onset of the next non-grace event.
Yes.
No.
Consuming software should decide on its own.
Upward.
Downward.
A decrease in dynamic level.
An increase in dynamic level.
G (treble) clef
F (bass) clef
C clef
Percussion clef
Jianpu clef
The slur is above the notes.
The slur is below the notes.
8va (notes are rendered down one octave)
8vb (notes are rendered up one octave)
15ma (notes are rendered down two octaves)
15mb (notes are rendered up two octaves)
22ma (notes are rendered down three octaves)
22mb (notes are rendered up three octaves)


The default value. The element should be displayed normally.

The element is not processed for display, and layout proceeds as if the element did not exist.

This is inspired by "display: none" from CSS.
Default. The element is visible.
The element is hidden.
Default. The element is performed.
The element is omitted from performance.
A curved symbol, similar to "{", that sits to the left of the system barline without touching it.
A straight line with curved ends that intersects the system barline just above and below the staves it includes.
A straight line that sits to the left of the system barline without touching it.
No symbol is displayed.
A straight line with straight ends that connect to the top and bottom staff lines of the staves it includes.
Use stem directions as defined by the first <part-layout> within this <voice-layout>.
Set all stem directions to up.
Set all stem directions to down.
Determine stem directions algorithmically according to notehead staff position.
Set all stem directions to up.
Set all stem directions to down.
Determine stem directions algorithmically according to notehead staff position.

fields.name: mnx
fields.description:
This is the top-level element of an MNX document.

Its child <head> element contains document metadata. Its child <global> element contains measure data that's shared by all parts. Its child <part> elements contain the bulk of the musical data — notes, rests, barlines, etc.

Its optional <score> elements contain information about specific engravings — including line breaks and page breaks.

fields.name: global
fields.description: The <global> element represents a set of measures, each of which provides content that is shared by a set of parts within the score. Examples of such content are key signatures and time signatures.

fields.name: measure-global
fields.description: The <measure-global> element is the place to encode global information about a measure — that is, the measure's metadata that applies to every <part> in the score. Examples are key signatures and time signatures.

fields.name: time
fields.description: The <time> element defines a time signature applicable to this and all following measure content, until changed. This is a staff direction. The measure location of a <time> direction is ignored and is assumed to be zero. It is invalid to place more than one <time> element within the same measure.

fields.name: part
fields.description: The <part> element represents a set of measures which describe a single part within the score. The sequence of measures must match the measure found in the <global> element applying to this part.

fields.name: measure
fields.description: The <measure> element is the place to encode the musical information for a given measure in a given part. This constitutes the majority of musical content in an MNX document.

fields.name: clef
fields.description: The <clef> element defines a clef associated with this staff.

fields.name: sequence
fields.description: The <sequence> element organizes a set of musical events within a measure into a strict temporal sequence, accompanied by relevant directions. To determine the measure position of each <event> within a <sequence>, you sequence the content, with a starting position 0 and time modification ratio 1. The content within each sequence supplies the music for a single polyphonic voice within its containing measure, including notes, chords, rests, tuplets and grace notes.

fields.name: event
fields.description: The <event> element represents a discrete period of time during which one or more notes are performed, or in which a rest occurs. All events other than whole-measure events require a value attribute to provide their duration as a note value. This duration is implicitly multiplied by the current time modification ratio, as specified by the process of sequencing the content of the event’s containing element. Note: It is legal for an event to have neither notes nor a rest. The result is functionally identical to <forward> but is more constrained since an event must have a valid note value, while a space can have a multiple thereof.

fields.name: note
fields.description: The <note> element defines a single note within an <event>, along with other information pertaining to the note itself rather than to its containing <event>.

fields.name: rest
fields.description: The <rest> element defines a rest within an <event>, along with other information pertaining to the rest rather than to its containing event.

fields.name: tied
fields.description: The <tied> element is used to indicate that a note is tied to a subsequent <note> element.

fields.name: beams
fields.description:
The <beams> element encodes all beams within a <sequence>.

Beams that are rendered in multiple sequences (i.e., beams that cross barlines) are encoded in the first sequence in which they appear.

fields.name: beam
fields.description:
The <beam> element describes a single beam.

A <beam> can contain nested <beam> elements, in the case of secondary beams. Each "level" of beam is encoded with a separate <beam> element.

fields.name: tuplet
fields.description: The <tuplet> element organizes a set of musical events that form a distinct and contiguous run within a sequence, and which are subject to a common time modification ratio expressed as the quotient of two rational numbers. A <tuplet> behaves much like a <sequence> with respect to its contents. The contents of the tuplet are placed into a temporal sequence by performing the procedure sequencing the content with a starting position determined by the parent context, and a time modification ratio equal to the tuplet’s outer value divided by its inner value. Following this procedure, the value of the sequence cursor MUST equal the value of inner, or the contents are considered to be in error.

fields.name: octave-shift
fields.description: An octave shift, traditionally notated with a marking such as "8va", tells a musician that the affected note(s) are being rendered a number of octaves up or down from their normal appearance on the staff, for sake of readability.

fields.name: ending
fields.description:
The <ending> element encodes an alternate ending, sometimes known as a "volta bracket."

Each alternate ending — say, the first ending to a repeated section — is encoded with two <ending> elements, one with type="start" and another with type="stop".

fields.name: grace
fields.description: The <grace> element encodes grace notes. It contains one or more <event> elements. Each inner <event> element's "value" attribute encodes the visual rhythmic appearance of the grace note — e.g., "/8" for an eighth note. Any direction content that lacks a location attribute and lives within a <grace> element is considered to be in alignment with the following <event>, even though grace notes in the same run technically share the same measure location.

fields.name: dynamics
fields.description:
Describes a textual dynamic direction to the performer.

The metrical position of this dynamic direction is determined by sequencing the content.

fields.name: instruction
fields.description: A run of text that is presented in a visual style consistent with general instructions to the performer. The content of this element is the text to be displayed. The metrical position of this text is determined by sequencing the content.

fields.name: expression
fields.description: A run of text that is presented in a visual style consistent with describing musical expression. The content of this element is the text to be displayed. The metrical position of this text is determined by sequencing the content.

fields.name: wedge
fields.description: A wedge, also known as a crescendo or diminuendo.

fields.name: cresc
fields.description: A crescendo or increasing dynamic level over the course of a span, notated as text followed by a dashed line.

fields.name: dim
fields.description: A diminuendo or decreasing dynamic level over the course of a span, notated as text followed by a dashed line.

fields.name: key
fields.description: The <key> element defines a key signature applicable to this and all following measure content, until changed. This is a staff direction. The measure location of a <key> direction is ignored and is assumed to be zero. The staff index of a <key> direction is ignored, as the direction always applies to all the staves in a given part (if not the whole score). It is invalid to place more than one <key> element within a single <measure> (or within a single <measure-global>). <key> elements in <global> are required for every key change. <key> elements below <part> are optional; if present, their "fifths" value must either be identical to the corresponding value in the global key or different by a multiple of 12.

fields.name: part-abbreviation
fields.description: The part's name in abbreviated form. For example, "Vln" for violin.

fields.name: head
fields.description: This element provides overall descriptive information for an MNX document, such as document-scoped metadata.

fields.name: forward
fields.description: The <forward> element represents a discrete period of time within a sequence in which no sequence content occurs. It embodies the idea of blank space within a measure.

fields.name: score
fields.description:
The <score> element represents a particular rendering of the music, with a defined subset of which parts are included, how they're visually arranged, where system breaks happen and where page breaks happen.

An MNX document can contain multiple <score> elements. For example, you can use this to define a "full score" vs. individual parts, within a single MNX file.

MNX documents are not required to contain a <score> element. If <score> isn't provided, the default rendering behavior is to include all parts — in the same order in which the <part> elements appear in the document — with line breaks and page breaks determined automatically by the consuming software.

A <score> element also is not required to contain any <page> elements. If <page> elements aren't provided, page breaks are to be determined automatically by the consuming software.

fields.name: page
fields.description:
The <page> element represents a single page of music — either printed (as on paper) or digitally rendered.

It's part of a <score> and contains a <system> element for each system of music in the page.

fields.name: system
fields.description:
The <system> element describes a system of notation — that is, a collection of staves that represent one or more measures across one or more parts.

This element is used in context of a <page>. Each <system> specifies its starting measure number and can optionally specify a system layout.

fields.name: system-layout
fields.description:
The <system-layout> element defines a visual layout that can be used by <system> or <score> elements.

For example, a layout might say "Include the vocal part, with the piano part directly below. For the piano part, use a grand-staff brace."

To encode this information, <system-layout> has the child elements <staff-layout> and <group-layout>.

fields.name: staff-layout
fields.description:
The <staff-layout> element describes the visual display of a single staff within a <system-layout>.

Generally this corresponds to a single <part>, but MNX supports encoding multiple parts in the same staff — as might be used, for example, when combining soprano and alto vocal parts into a single stave.

You must have at least one child <part-layout> or <voice-layout> element, to specify which part(s) are displayed within this staff layout.

fields.name: group-layout
fields.description:
The <group-layout> element is a way to group <staff-layout> elements together, for the purposes of giving them a unified name and/or grouping symbol.

You can also nest <group-layout> elements within another, to represent more complex groupings of staves, as in large orchestral scores.

fields.name: part-layout
fields.description: The <part-layout> element is the way to specify which <part>s are included in a given <staff-layout> or <voice-layout>.

fields.name: tempo
fields.description: The <tempo> element defines a tempo, from the point of its occurrence forward until changed. The tempo is rendered as a conventional pairing of a small beat unit notation equated to a metronome marking.

fields.name: layouts
fields.description: The <layouts> element is a container for <system-layout> elements.

fields.name: voice-layout
fields.description: The <voice-layout> element lets you combine multiple <part>s into a single voice of a <staff-layout>. This is useful for complex orchestral scores, where individual parts are sometimes placed on multiple staves but sometimes placed on a single staff.

fields.name: system-layout-change
fields.description: The <system-layout-change> element lets you indicate a change in <system-layout> in the middle of a system — usually, but not necessarily, due to changes in stemming.

fields.name: style
fields.description: The <style> element is a way to define visual styling within an MNX document. Its required selector attribute specifies which MNX element(s) the style applies to. See Styling an MNX document for more. This example defines a style class "emphasized", which means to use the color red: <style selector=".emphasized" color="#ff0000"> A <note> element can then use the "class" attribute to use this style class: <note class="emphasized" ...> This example says "all <note> elements must be blue": <style selector="note" color="#0000ff"> At the moment, the only available style property is "color".

fields.name: sign
fields.description: The clef sign.

fields.name: line
fields.description: The staff line associated with the clef sign.

fields.name: value
fields.description: The duration of this event. This is required unless this event has measure="yes".

fields.name: pitch
fields.description: The note's pitch.

fields.name: accidental
fields.description: The accidental to be rendered for this note. This must match the alteration of the "pitch" attribute. Omission of this attribute indicates that no accidental is to be displayed.

fields.name: target
fields.description:
The ID of a <note> that lies in the same part, and whose containing <event> begins directly after the end of the of this note’s <event>. The step, alteration and octave values for the target note must be identical to this one.

If target is not provided, the tie does not connect to a particular destination note. In this case, the "location" attribute may be used to specify the location of the other end of the tie.

fields.name: events
fields.description: A space-separated list of event IDs for events that comprise this beam — in order by their position in the beam.

fields.name: inner
fields.description:
The duration of the enclosed content, as notated.

For example, a quarter-note triplet would have inner="3/4". Its inner duration is three quarter notes (3 * 1/4 = 3/4).

fields.name: outer
fields.description:
The duration of this tuplet with respect to its containing element. This is how much time the tuplet occupies in the <measure> (or parent <tuplet>, in case of nested tuplets) in which it is placed.

For example, a quarter-note triplet would have outer="1/2".

fields.name: type
fields.description: The type of octave shift.

fields.name: side
fields.description: The slur's side. If not provided, the consuming software should determine the value automatically according to its own logic.

fields.name: target
fields.description:
If provided, this specifies the ID of the slur’s end <event> — that is, the last event over which this slur is rendered. This ID must exist in the document and must identify an event.

If not provided, the slur does not connect to a particular destination <event>. In this case, the "location" attribute may be used to specify the location of the other end of the slur.

fields.name: location
fields.description:
The value of location may lie either before or after the slur’s event, or it may use the special values "incoming" or "outgoing". The handling is as follows:

* If the location precedes the start of the current event, this signifies a slur starting at the given location and ending on the current event.

* If the location occurs after the start of the current event, this signifies a slur starting at the current event and ending at the given location.

* A value of "incoming" places the start location at a conventionally short distance before the current event, and ends on the current event.

* A value of "outgoing" starts on the current event, and places the end location at a conventionally short distance after the current event.

If neither target nor location is given, the effect is as if location="outgoing" was specified.

fields.name: start-note
fields.description:
The ID of the specific note at which this slur starts. This note must be within the <event> that contains this >slur>.

For example, you can use start-note to encode which specific note, within a chord, a slur is intended to start on — in cases when an engraving has multiple slurs starting on the same >event>.

fields.name: end-note
fields.description:
The ID of the specific note at which this slur ends. This note must be within the <event> specified by this slur's "target" attribute.

For example, you can use end-note to encode which specific note, within a chord, a slur is intended to end on — in cases when an engraving has multiple slurs end on the same >event>.

fields.name: line-type
fields.description: The slur's line type. If not provided, the consuming software should determine the value automatically according to its own logic.

fields.name: side-end
fields.description: The slur’s side at the end of the slur, in cases where it differs from its initial side — for example, in cross-staff notation. If not provided, it's interpreted to have the same value as "side".

fields.name: type
fields.description: The kind of grace notes included in this element. The default value is "steal-previous".

fields.name: slash
fields.description:
Whether grace notes are notated with a slash.

The default value of "yes" specifies a slash, indicating that the grace notes are displayed with a diagonal stroke and are to be performed quickly and not in their notated rhythm. Otherwise, they are performed with the notated note values according to the performance characteristics given by "type".

fields.name: orient
fields.description: A specific orientation for this tuplet. If not provided, the orientation is inherited from any ancestor element that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the orientation is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules.

fields.name: orient
fields.description: The default orientation of the content in this sequence. If not provided, the orientation is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules and may be overridden by descendant elements.

fields.name: staff
fields.description: The staff index to which this direction applies, if such a designation makes sense. If not provided, the value is inherited from any sequence ancestor that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the consuming software should determine the value automatically according to its own logic.

fields.name: orient
fields.description: A specific orientation for this direction. If not provided, the value is inherited from any sequence ancestor that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the consuming software should determine the value automatically according to its own logic.

fields.name: end
fields.description: The measure location of the last event that is affected by this direction. This measure location must lie within the same run of measure content as this direction's start position.

fields.name: type
fields.description: The type of wedge.

fields.name: text
fields.description: Overrides the text to be displayed in the score for this element.

fields.name: text
fields.description: Overrides the text to be displayed in the score for this element.

fields.name: fifths
fields.description: The number of fifths distance from a signature with no accidentals.

fields.name: measure
fields.description:
This overrides the notated time signature for the current measure only, where this value differs from "signature". This is of particular use for anacruses and for shortened measures prior to a repeat or jump back to an anacrusis.

The "measure" attribute must be provided in all cases where the actual content of a measure is of a different length from that indicated by "signature". MNX does not require consumer implementations to examine the contents of measures to determine their intended length.

fields.name: octave
fields.description: The number of octaves by which the pitches normally indicated by the given clef sign should be transposed. Default is zero.

fields.name: glyph
fields.description: A specific SMuFL glyph name to be used when rendering this dynamic.

fields.name: glyph
fields.description: A specific SMuFL glyph name to be used when rendering this symbol.

fields.name: glyph
fields.description: A specific SMuFL glyph name to be used when rendering this clef, e.g. gClefArrowUp. See SMuFL clef glyphs.

fields.name: stem-direction
fields.description: Whether the stem of the note(s) in this event is up or down. If not provided, this is left to consuming software to decide automatically.

fields.name: staff
fields.description: The default staff index of the content in this sequence. If not provided, the orientation is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules and may be overridden by descendant elements.

fields.name: voice
fields.description: A string that identifies the voice to which this sequence belongs. All <sequence> elements in a given <part> having the same value of "voice" belong to the same voice. Within a given <measure> element, no two <sequence> elements may share the same value for voice. The value of voice is an opaque identifier that does not supply information from producers to consumers.

fields.name: measure
fields.description: Whether this event is a whole-measure event — meaning its duration lasts the entire measure. This is used, for example, for rests that last an entire measure. If this value is set to "yes", then this event may not specify "value" and this event must either be empty or contain exactly one <rest>.

fields.name: orient
fields.description: A specific orientation for this event. If not provided, the orientation is inherited from any ancestor element that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the orientation is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules.

fields.name: staff
fields.description:
A specific staff index for this event. If not provided, the value is inherited from any ancestor element that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the value is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules.

The primary purpose of this attribute is to override a default staff assignment at the <sequence> level — as in cross-staff keyboard notation.

fields.name: duration
fields.description: The actual, performed duration of the event, if different from the notated value given by "value". Note that this is specified as a note value quantity, rather than a rhythmic duration, because the former is less constrained. It may be any desired multiple of a note value. The duration attribute not only alters the performance of the event, but determines the amount of time the event takes up in the measure, affecting the location of subsequent events in the containing sequence. This can change the layout of the measure, as subsequent <event>s will occur earlier or later as a result and be positioned accordingly (see sequencing the content). It also affects the validation of the measure for metrical correctness. This attribute is unlikely to be frequently encountered, but it's needed to handle cases in which composers use notated values that are not interpreted literally.

fields.name: duration
fields.description: The metrical duration of this space. Note that, in contrast to the <event> value attribute, this duration attribute is not constrained to a single note value, but may be a multiple of one.

fields.name: location
fields.description:
The value of location may lie either before or after the slur’s event, or it may use the special values "incoming" or "outgoing". The handling is as follows:

* If the location precedes the start of the current event, this signifies a tie starting at the given location and ending on the current note.

* If the location occurs after the start of the current event, this signifies a tie starting at the current note and ending at the given location.

* A value of "incoming" places the start location at a conventionally short distance before the current note, and ends on the current note.

* A value of "outgoing" starts on the current note, and places the end location at a conventionally short distance after the current note.

If neither target nor location is given, the effect is as if location="outgoing" was specified.

fields.name: pitch
fields.description: If provided, this mandates that the rest be placed on the staff line corresponding to the provided chromatic pitch. The accidental component of the pitch is ignored for this purpose.

fields.name: staff
fields.description:
A specific staff index for this note. If not provided, the value is inherited from any ancestor element that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the value is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules.

The primary purpose of this attribute is to override a default staff assignment at the <sequence> or <event> level — as in cross-staff keyboard notation.

fields.name: staff
fields.description:
A specific staff index for this tuplet. If not provided, the value is inherited from any ancestor element that specified it. If no ancestor did so, the value is determined automatically according to the implementation’s rendering rules.

The primary purpose of this attribute is to override a default staff assignment at the <sequence> level — as in cross-staff keyboard notation.

fields.name: show-number
fields.description:
Controls the display of the quantity of inner and outer note value units for the tuplet.

* "none" — do not show any tuplet number.

* "inner" (default) — display only the numerator of the tuplet's "inner" attribute.

* "both" — display both the numerators of the tuplet's "inner" and "outer" attributes.

fields.name: show-value
fields.description:
Controls the display of the note value units used inside and outside the tuplet.

* "none" (default) — do not show any tuplet units.

* "inner" — display only the note value unit of the tuplet’s "inner" attribute.

* "both" — display both the note value units of the tuplet's "inner" and "outer" attributes.

fields.name: bracket
fields.description:
Controls the display of a bracket in conjunction with the tuplet. This is disregarded if "show-number" has a value of "none".

* "auto" (default) — a bracket is shown for the tuplet if and only if the notes are unbeamed.

* "yes" — always display a bracket.

* "no" — never display a bracket.

fields.name: smufl-font
fields.description: The SMuFL-compliant font to be used to render notational objects in this part. Can be overridden by certain child elements.

fields.name: smufl-font
fields.description:
The SMuFL-compliant font to be used when rendering this note.

The primary purpose of this attribute is to override a global font assignment.

fields.name: smufl-font
fields.description:
The SMuFL-compliant font to be used when rendering this event.

The primary purpose of this attribute is to override a global font assignment.

fields.name: perform
fields.description: Controls whether this note is performed by consuming software.

fields.name: staves
fields.description:
The number of staves that this part uses. For example, use the value 2 for a grand staff (as used in piano music).

If not provided, the default is 1.

fields.name: name
fields.description:
The score name, suitable for display to people viewing or selecting this particular score within music notation software.

Examples: "Full score", "Flute 1 part".

fields.name: measure
fields.description: Specifies the starting measure in this system. This corresponds to the "index" attribute of the <measure> element.

fields.name: id
fields.description: A unique identifier for this system layout. This is used by the <system> (or <score>) element to specify which layout the system (or score) uses.

fields.name: symbol
fields.description:
The symbol to use along the left vertical edge of this staff. If omitted, the default value is "none".

Note that the parent <staff-group> might also define its own "symbol" attribute.

fields.name: label
fields.description:
An optional name for this staff. If provided, this should be rendered to the left of the staff.

Generally we recommend using "labelref" instead of "label", to avoid duplication of data within an MNX document.

fields.name: labelref
fields.description:
If provided, this specifies that the corresponding part's name (or short-name) should be rendered to the left of the staff.

By using this instead of the "label" attribute, you can avoid needing to duplicate a part's name in an MNX document.

fields.name: symbol
fields.description:
The symbol to use along the left vertical edge of this group of staves. If omitted, the default value is "none".

Note that the child <staff-layout> or <group-layout> elements might also define their own own "symbol" attributes.

fields.name: label
fields.description: An optional name for this group of staves. If provided, this should be rendered to the left of the staff group.

fields.name: layout
fields.description:
An optional layout to use for this system. If provided, this should be the ID of a <system-layout> element in the same MNX document.

This overrides any layout specified by the parent <page> or <score> elements.

fields.name: layout
fields.description:
An optional layout to use for all systems in this score. If provided, this should be the ID of a <system-layout> element in the same MNX document.

Note that individual <system> elements within this <score> can optionally override this.

fields.name: layout
fields.description:
An optional layout to use for the systems in this page. If provided, this should be the ID of a <system-layout> element in the same MNX document.

This overrides the layout specified by the parent <score> element. It can be overridden on a per-system basis in child &tl;system> elements.

fields.name: id
fields.description: An optional ID for this part. This is used by other elements in the same MNX document in cases when they need to refer to a specific part (or parts).

fields.name: name
fields.description: An optional name for this part. Notation software might use this in instrument-selection UI, and/or it might be rendered to the left of this part's staves (see the <staff> element).

fields.name: short-name
fields.description:
An optional abbreviated name for this part. Notation software might use this in instrument-selection UI, and/or it might be rendered to the left of this part's staves (see the <staff> element).

For example, the system in a piece of music might use the name "Guitar", while subsequent systems might use the abbreviated "Gtr." instead.

fields.name: part
fields.description: A reference to the appropriate <part>.

fields.name: part-staff
fields.description: Optional staff index within the given <part>. For example, this lets you filter the <part> to only include the notation data with staff=1 (the top staff of a grand staff).

fields.name: index
fields.description: The one-based index of this measure within the document's score order. The default value is 1 for the first <measure> in <global>. For all other measures, the default value is the value of the previous <measure> plus 1. This is used within the MNX document in cases when content needs to refer to a specific measure.

fields.name: number
fields.description: A visual label for the measure. It is not required to be unique in the document. If omitted, its value is the same as index.

fields.name: barline
fields.description:
The barline drawn at the end of this measure. If not provided, the barline should be interpreted as follows:

* If the measure is the last in the document, use "light-heavy".
* Otherwise, use "regular".

fields.name: value
fields.description: A note value which is asserted to occur with a frequency of bpm times per minute.

fields.name: bpm
fields.description: The number of times per minute the given value should occur.

fields.name: location
fields.description: The measure location of this tempo marking. If not provided, the default value is zero.

fields.name: location
fields.description: The measure location of this direction.

fields.name: location
fields.description: The measure location of this direction.

fields.name: location
fields.description: The measure location of this direction.

fields.name: stem
fields.description:
The stem direction to use for all notes within this <voice-layout>. Default is "part", which means to use stem directions as defined in the first child <part-layout>.

If this value is "up", "down" or "float", then stem directions in the underlying <part> are ignored within this <voice-layout>.

fields.name: label
fields.description:
An optional name for this voice. If provided, this should be rendered to the left of the staff, vertically positioned such that it aligns with the voice position (either above center or below center).

Generally we recommend using "labelref" instead of "label", to avoid duplication of data within an MNX document.

fields.name: labelref
fields.description:
If provided, this specifies that the corresponding part's name (or short-name) should be rendered to the left of the staff.

By using this instead of the "label" attribute, you can avoid needing to duplicate a part's name in an MNX document.

If this <voice-layout> contains multiple <part-layout> elements, the first <part-layout> child should be used.

fields.name: stem
fields.description: The stem direction to use for all notes within the associated <part>. Default is "float", meaning the stem directions should be determined algorithmically.

fields.name: part-voice
fields.description:
Optional voice ID within the given <part>. This allows you to filter the associated <part>'s <sequence> data by voice.

If this is not provided, the <part-layout> will use all the notation data from the <part> (i.e., applying no filter).

fields.name: class
fields.description: An optional style class to use for this element and all child elements.

fields.name: color
fields.description: An optional color to be used when rendering this element and all child elements.

fields.name: selector
fields.description:
A CSS-style selector that specifies which MNX element(s) this style applies to.

Currently MNX supports two types of selectors, element selectors and style selectors.

fields.name: color
fields.description: The color to apply to any elements targeted by this style.

fields.name: “Hello world”
fields.blurb: This basic MNX document contains a single middle C whole note, on a treble clef stave, in 4/4 time.
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global barline="regular">
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/1">
                    <note pitch="C4"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Two-bar C major scale
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global  barline="regular" />
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="D4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="F4"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="A4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="B4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Three-note chord and half rest
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global barline="regular">
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence><metadiff>
                <event value="/2">
                    <note pitch="C4"/>
                    <note pitch="E4"/>
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/2">
                    <rest/>
                </event>
            </metadiff></sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Time signatures
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <metadiff><global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global/>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="2/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
    </global></metadiff>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="D5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="F5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="D5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="F5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="B4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="D5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Key signatures
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
                <metadiff><key fifths="4"/></metadiff>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global/>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <metadiff><key fifths="-4"/></metadiff>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global/>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="F#5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="G#5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/1">
                    <note pitch="G#5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="Ab4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="Bb4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="Ab4"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/1">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Accidentals
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
                <key fifths="-2"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global/>
        <measure-global/>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="F4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <metadiff><note pitch="G#4" accidental="sharp"/></metadiff>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="A4"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/2">
                    <note pitch="Bb4"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <metadiff><note pitch="Db5" accidental="flat"/></metadiff>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="Db5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/1">
                    <metadiff><note pitch="D5" accidental="natural"/></metadiff>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Dotted notes (augmentation dots)
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <metadiff><event value="/4d">
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event></metadiff>
                <event value="/8">
                    <note pitch="E5"/>
                </event>
                <metadiff><event value="/4d">
                    <note pitch="F4"/>
                    <note pitch="D5"/>
                </event></metadiff>
                <event value="/8">
                    <note pitch="F5"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Ties
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global/>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef sign="G" line="2"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E5">
                        <metadiff><tied target="note3"/></metadiff>
                    </note>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="E5" id="note3"/>
                </event>
                <event value="/4">
                    <note pitch="C5">
                        <metadiff><tied target="note5"/></metadiff>
                    </note>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <event value="/2">
                    <note pitch="C5" id="note5">
                        <metadiff><tied target="note6"/></metadiff>
                    </note>
                </event>
                <event value="/2">
                    <note pitch="C5" id="note6"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
    </part>
</mnx>

fields.name: Beams
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>
        <measure-global>
            <directions-global>
                <time signature="4/4"/>
            </directions-global>
        </measure-global>
        <measure-global/>
    </global>
    <part name="Music">
        <measure>
            <directions-part>
                <clef line="2" sign="G"/>
            </directions-part>
            <sequence>
                <metadiff><beams>
                    <beam events="ev1 ev2 ev3 ev4"/>
                    <beam events="ev5 ev6 ev7 ev8"/>
                </beams></metadiff>
                <event id="ev1" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="C5"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev2" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="D5"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev3" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="E5"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev4" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="F5"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev5" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="D4"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev6" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="E4"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev7" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="F4"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev8" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                </event>
            </sequence>
        </measure>
        <measure>
            <sequence>
                <metadiff><beams>
                    <beam events="ev9 ev10 ev11 ev12 ev13">
                        <beam events="ev11 ev12"/>
                    </beam>
                    <beam events="ev14 ev15"/>
                </beams></metadiff>
                <event id="ev9" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev10" value="/8">
                    <rest/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev11" value="/16">
                    <note pitch="D4"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev12" value="/16">
                    <note pitch="E4"/>
                </event>
                <event id="ev13" value="/8">
                    <note pitch="G4"/>
                </event>

fields.name: System layouts
fields.document:
<mnx>
    <global>...</global>
    <part id="fl1" name="Flute 1" short-name="1">...</part>
    <part id="fl2" name="Flute 2" short-name="2">...</part>
    <part id="fl3" name="Flute 3" short-name="3">...</part>
    <part id="ob1" name="Oboe 1" short-name="1">...</part>
    <part id="ob2" name="Oboe 2" short-name="2">...</part>
    <part id="piano" name="Piano" staves="2">...</part>

    <layouts>
        <system-layout id="layout1">
            <group-layout symbol="bracket">
                <group-layout symbol="brace" label="Flutes">
                    <staff-layout>
                        <voice-layout stem="up" labelref="short-name">
                            <part-layout part="fl1" />
                        </voice-layout>
                        <voice-layout stem="down" labelref="short-name">
                            <part-layout part="fl2" />
                        </voice-layout>
                    </staff-layout>
                    <staff-layout labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="fl3" />
                    </staff-layout>
                </group-layout>
                <staff-layout label="Oboes">
                    <voice-layout stem="up" labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="ob1" />
                    </voice-layout>
                    <voice-layout stem="down" labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="ob2" />
                    </voice-layout>
                </staff-layout>
            </group-layout>
            <group-layout symbol="brace" label="Piano">
                <staff-layout>
                    <part-layout part="piano" part-staff="1" />
                </staff-layout>
                <staff-layout>
                    <part-layout part="piano" part-staff="2" />
                </staff-layout>
            </group-layout>
        </system-layout>
        <system-layout id="layout2">
            <group-layout symbol="bracket">
                <group-layout symbol="brace" label="Fl.">
                    <staff-layout labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="fl1" />
                    </staff-layout>
                    <staff-layout labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="fl2" />
                    </staff-layout>
                    <staff-layout labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="fl3" />
                    </staff-layout>
                </group-layout>
                <staff-layout name="Ob.">
                    <voice-layout stem="up" labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="ob1" />
                    </voice-layout>
                    <voice-layout stem="down" labelref="short-name">
                        <part-layout part="ob2" />
                    </voice-layout>
                </staff-layout>
            </group-layout>
            <group-layout symbol="brace" label="Piano">
                <staff-layout>
                    <part-layout part="piano" part-staff="1" />
                </staff-layout>
                <staff-layout>
                    <part-layout part="piano" part-staff="2" />
                </staff-layout>
            </group-layout>
        </system-layout>
    </layouts>

    <score name="Full score">
        <page>
            <system measure="1" layout="layout1" />
            <system measure="4" layout="layout2" />
        </page>
    </score>
</mnx>
